data.question: What is the main purpose of synthesizing luminescent MOF materials?
data.answer: The main purpose is to generate luminescent platforms for probing volatile organic molecules (VOMs) by tuning the energy transfer efficiency between two different emissions.

data.question: What unique feature does the synthesized luminescent MOF material contain?
How does the dye@MOF platform exhibit its sensing capability?
data.answer: By showing excellent fingerprint correlation between the VOM and the emission peak-height ratio of ligand to dye moieties.

data.question: True or False: The dye@MOF sensor is not stable.
What method was used to quantify the access to the pores in CZJ-3?
What happens to the framework structure of CZJ-3 when embedded with Rhodamine B?
True or False: The emission peak height of Rhodamine B in Rho@CZJ-3 cannot be used for probing small molecules.
What is the coordination environment of CdII ions in CZJ-3?
data.answer: The Cd cation is coordinating to six carboxyl oxygen atoms from five L ligands and one water molecule.

data.question: How does the structure of CZJ-3 change upon removal of included solvent molecules?
data.answer: CZJ-3 loses its long-range order upon removal of the included solvent molecules.

data.question: True or False: The structure of CZJ-3 is not flexible and does not depend on the solvent guests.
What is the effect of different VOMs on the emission intensities of Rho@CZJ-3?
data.answer: The emission intensities of Rho@CZJ-3 are very sensitive to the included solvent molecules by tuning the energy transfer from L to dye moieties.

data.question: True or False: The emission peak-height ratio of ligand to dye moieties in Rho@CZJ-3 is variable for each guest and different solvent molecules.
What does the emission-fingerprint map of VOMs based on the photoluminescence of Rho@CZJ-3 help to overcome?
data.answer: It helps to overcome the drawback of variable solid-state emission intensities encountered when probing VOMs by a single emissive transition.

data.question: True or False: The luminescent sensor Rho@CZJ-3 requires additional calibration for probing a range of solvent molecules.
What is the main advantage of the luminescent dye@MOF platform over traditional luminescent sensors?
data.answer: It offers excellent fingerprint correlation between the solvent and emission peak-height ratio of ligand to dye moieties, making it more stable and reliable.

data.question: True or False: The emission colors of Rho@CZJ-3 cannot be systematically modulated by tuning the excitation energy.
What is the role of the ligand-to-dye energy transfer behaviors in the functionality of Rho@CZJ-3?
data.answer: It confirms that the emission energy of the ligand matches well with the excitation energy of the dye, enhancing the luminescence of Rho@CZJ-3.

data.question: True or False: The quantum yields of Rho@CZJ-3 are lower than that of CZJ-3.
How does the sensing stability of the luminescent Rho@CZJ-3 manifest?
data.answer: The sensing stability is shown by recycling experiments where the relative emission intensity between L and dye moieties is almost constant for 15 cycles in sensing benzene molecules.

data.question: True or False: The luminescent dye@MOF approach is limited in its practical applications for sensitizing and probing different substrate molecules/ions.
